characters: EXT. EDGE OF THE BATTLEFIELDS. DUSK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bucolic magnificence of the Devon countryside. We fly low over the high, thick hedges untouched for hundreds of years. The thick verdant countryside in all its splendor, ancient woodlands, fields of corn, and finally a paddock typical Devonshire dale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We come to rest beside three farmers standing over a preg mare. The mare is in distress - she is about to give birt The farmers calm the mare and tend to her gently with assurance and authority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull back to see, ALBERT, a fifteen-year-old farm boy, watching the whole drama with delight from the paddock ga

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, easy, girl. Easy, girl. Easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men hold the mare firmly, but clearly this is a diffi birth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a stubborn one, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There we go. Who's a clever girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later - the summer's sun glints off the wet, stic hide of the foal (JOEY) - red hide, four white socks and distinctive white cross on its forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon the creature is attempting its first clumsy steps. I both awesome and comical to see the new born creature struggle to his feet, but eventually, he succeeds. Title: WAR HORSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow Joey's progress over the course of his first ye His initial fearfulness, his connection with his mother, intimacy of their relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joey gets strong they run together, frolicking gayly i the last dregs of summer. Albert looking on. Joey notices at the fence and they share a moment of connection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spring: flowers are beginning to sprout by the hedgerows. boy Albert runs into the field. He takes an apple from hi pocket - he holds it out tentatively. Joey approaches Alb with suspicion. Albert gently encourages him. 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His mother paws the ground and neighs at Joey. He turns a runs over the field at her beck and call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert tosses the apple to himself, ruefully - watches in as Joey races away with his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is a magnificent one year old. His distinctive red coa gleaming, now it is clear that he is half thoroughbred. H runs quickly around the field enjoying his own power and strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later - the three farmers open the gate and come into the field. Both Joey and his mother instinctively canter over the two men, expecting food. The three men gently greet t horses and pet them, then we see one man has a noose made a rope. He slips it round Mum's neck. She pulls back, Joe shaken and bewildered but before he knows what's happenin the second farmer is trying to get a similar rope around neck. Joey balks and pushes the farmer aside, distressed see his mother tethered. The farmer grabs Joey again and struggles with him, enlisting the help of the second farm With some effort they get the rope around his neck and ca him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy does it. Easy does it. Come on, steady does it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unused to being tethered Joey pulls at the rope but the farmers are solid and firm. They gently lead Joey and his mother across the field to the gate and out into the road

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole road becomes overtaken by a flock of sheep on t way to the market. In the distance we hear the bustle of Market Day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The farmers lead Joey and his mother through the chaos of market and into an auction pen. They find themselves amon a hoard of pigs, sheep and cows. Joey is agog at all of t creatures and all this life he had no idea existed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The farmers lead the horses into a stall to await the auction. Joey is bewildered by all the noise - buttressed against a couple of mules and a cow. He is uncomfortable this tight space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An AUCTION WORKER holds a clipboard out for the lead farm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mornin', pop. Put your mark here. Good luck. 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two men approach the pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the colt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One man grabs Joey and pulls him out of the pen. Suddenly there is a look of horror on his face. His terrified moth realises they are being separated. Joey panics and desperately tries to get back to his mother, he rises up throwing the man who is leading him aside. Joey is out of control. The man regains control of Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa! Whoa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls Joey away from his mother, who lets out a heart- rending cry, paws the ground, and crashes her foreleg aga the fence. Joey remains disoriented in the midst of the market day chaos.

dialogues.speaker: AUCTION MAN 3, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Easy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The auction ring is full of people of all shapes and size There is a sense of celebration and busyness about market day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We concentrate on two men - Ted Narracott (DAD), in his forties, clearly both the cares of the world and alcohol worn him down before his time, and SI EASTON, his more so friend, both working farmers. Just behind Si is his 15 ye old son, ANDREW. Ted has a drink in his hand. They all lo at Joey bridling against the men who are trying to hold h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's a beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it, Ted. He's half thoroughbred and not got a day's work in him. (points to a plow horse next to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, there... There's your ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In contrast to Joey, the solid and bulky plow horse stand like a rock. But Dad remains fixated on Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But look at him, Si. Look at that creature. 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, Joey is magnificent, his power clearly emerging because of his upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be daft. You need something solid to plow a field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fixed on Joey) Yeah, but he's something else, that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The AUCTIONEER announces the start of the auction...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright gentlemen - settle down - settle down - horses on my right - men with money in their pockets on my left - it's the perfect combination. Is Fred Goddard here? FRED shouts his reply from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YES! I's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good - more money than sense. Dave Hill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here. Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bugger off, you tight bastard - you've been coming here for 20 years - never bought so much as a pork scratching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd are loving all this. Dad notices a figure across the ring, LYONS, clearly a ma money. You can see something light up in Dad's eyes - a combination of dislike and alcohol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey is led into the auction pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay - first up today - a gorgeous young horse - prettiest thing I've seen since my wife on our wedding day. Let's get going, shall we? Who wants this wonderful creature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But no-one bids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One guinea. 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One guinea, one guinea, one guinea...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ANDREW EASTON
dialogues.text: I thought you needed a plow horse, Mister Narracott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any advance on one guinea? Any advance on one guinea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey is still trying to get back to his mother. A voice f the crowd pipes up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two guineas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted Narracott - it's completely the wrong animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyons whispers to his son, DAVID, 15, next to him. David Joey skeptically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si Easton - I'm not gonna let that bastard see me off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five guineas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh for the love of...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey is straining to get to his mother, the men are pulli him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greedy sod thinks he can just buy anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight. 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it - he's your landlord - you can't be picking fights with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyons looks over. There is now tension in the crowd as th sense a Battle Royal for the horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten guineas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smirks at Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't got the money. Let's go home - let's have a pint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven guineas, sir, from as good a man as any in this town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all look at Lyons in his suit and bowler hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I hear twelve guineas? Twelve guineas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's top price for a workin' animal. Ted! Save it for the shire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are big days and there are small days. Which will it be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I hear any advance on eleven guineas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes are on Lyons and his son - David is 15, smartly dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just let him go, dad, I don't care for him, he's too... jumpy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyons isn't listening to David; he's looking hard at Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we say - twenty five?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd gasps. This is clearly personal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's got you there. Nice try, Ted. 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were great, Mr N. Gave him a run for his money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But when he looks at Ted, Ted's eyes are locked into the of his rival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going, going...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty. Thirty guineas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Total silence. He stares hard at Lyons. Who simply smiles raises an eyebrow, tips his hat and walks away. It dawns Dad that he's won the auction. He breaks into a sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty guineas. Thirty guineas. Going going gone - to Mister Ted Narracott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bangs his gavel. It's a done deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you done, Ted? What have you done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad doesn't acknowledge Si.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later - Ted stands staring at Joey, who looks bac Ted holds his reins numbly, accepts his receipt from the auction man in a kind of daze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Lyons appears at Dad's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite a beast, there. But what you gonna do with him - on a working farm? I hope you got the rent, Ted. I'll be around for it when it comes due.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad does not acknowledge Lyons. Lyons smiles and walks aw with son David, and his cronies. Si shakes his head at Da

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a fool, Ted. And our Rosie'll never forgive you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. NARRACOTT kneels in her garden, digging up some carr when she sees Ted returning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad walks down the hedged lane as the sun sets pulling Jo with him, his bad leg always moving slightly to the side. 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Narracott looks in horror and bewilderment at Joey a then at Dad. She is a good-looking, intelligent woman, bu clearly her life is always hard.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: What have you done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad stands shamefaced as Albert - the boy we have already - runs out of the house to join them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Mooney's colt!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: You were supposed to buy a plow horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bought him?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: What'd you pay for him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert is totally taken by the horse.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How much, Ted Narracott?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't tell you a lie - though I would love to. Thirty guineas.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: Thirty guineas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is stunned. She looks at Ted - and he just nods.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He's not worth ten! Are you out of your mind? What about the rent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a strong one, Rosie. Look at the way he holds his head!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: How the hell are we gonna pull anything with that? Ted - you have to take him back. You have to take him back right now now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. 9.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: You have to get down on your knees and beg for our money back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey bridles at the raised voices but Albert takes the ro and tries to calm him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No, please don't take him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly we see Dad's dejection. He is a man lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't take him back till he's broken in.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: And how are you gonna train a horse with that leg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll train him.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: No, you stay out of this, Albie. You don't know nothing about horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mum. Please let me. I can do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to keep him. We've no choice.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: Right. Well... you've got one month to break him in or I'm taking him back myself. (She turns to the house, but then...) How did you get to thirty - what other fool bid you up that high?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Lyons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Narracott turns back towards the house, then stops, dazed, speaking almost to herself.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: We're gonna lose everything. After all we've been through - we're gonna lose it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns back to the others - the weight of the mistake heavy on their shoulders - but Albert quickly steps forwa 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Mum - I'll raise him - and I'll raise him good.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: Well, you better. Go on - get started. See if a child can undo what your fool of a father's done to this family of ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Narracott storms into the house. Albert immediately goes to stroke Joey but the nervous horse draws back uncomfortably. Dad leads him off, drunk and bewildered, across the yard to the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert loads some oats into a bucket and approaches Joey the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Let's make a start then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Albert approaches, Joey nervously runs in circles, the stops on a dime, looking at Albert suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's oats. Very tasty, that is. It's beef and gravy to us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert squats down. He shows the food. Joey catches the scent on the air, but still hesitates and shies away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time, Albert takes a new tact, almost turning his bo fully away from Joey, but keeping the bucket extended. Albert slowly backs towards Joey, speaking gently all the while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you're missing your mother. Look at you... first time without your mum. First time away from home. But you're not alone, are you. In fact. Cos I'm `ere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feeling safer, Joey moves toward the bucket of oats and starts to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright. It's alright. 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert reaches out his hand and touches Joey. And with a slight start, the horse relaxes into Albert's hand, feeli safe with the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert stares at the distinctive white cross on Joey's forehead. Joey calms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna call you Joey. Understand? Joey. That's you. And I'm Albert. It's alright, You're mine now. You're mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert strokes Joey's forehead. Joey lifts his head and t two stare at each other in close proximity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, with a hangover, hobbles off to work the fields. As reaches the gate, HAROLD the goose snaps at his heels. Da dismisses him with a stare and heads for the stables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The training episode: Albert walks Joey around the yard o the rope. It all seems to be going well. Mum looks on. Al is clearly proud of his progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert's friend, Andrew Easton, sits on a rock with an ap in hand to watch the training.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert sets Joey in a spot and tells him to wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa. I want you to stay there, Joey. Stay. That's it. Good boy. That's it, you've got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course when Albert walks away, Joey follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A game of "Grandma's footsteps" ensues as Albert patientl places Joey then walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, look at him, Albie. He's playing "Grandma's Footsteps."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert patiently leads Joey back to his starting position

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, come on, Joey. Back you go. Come on. Back you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all right. That's it. Good boy. Right. You've gotta stay there, understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert walks away again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. Good boy. You've got it. Good boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally Joey stays put. Andrew smiles, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good boy. Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now call him. Whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come now, Joey. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert whistles like an owl. Joey stands completely still

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can come now, Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He whistles again. Joey remains still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think he fancies your owls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert walks back to Joey, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I read it in a story. It's how the Indians used to summon their horses. He gently strokes Joey's nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Joey, when I whistle, you've gotta come, understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dad had a dog who stayed when you called him. He used to run up behind you when you weren't looking, and uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not a dog. He's just puzzling it through. 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert runs further away than before and whistles. After moment, Joey trots over to him. Andrew smiles broadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brilliant. Look at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the basis established, Albert begins to train Joey t react to the owl whistle without his prompting. It's not easy going - sometimes Albert makes progress, sometimes n

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUICK MONTAGE - Mrs. Narracott fills a bucket at the pump then promptly spills it when Joey trots past her in respo to an owl whistle. She calls off, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: Albie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad heads out to the fields with a rake on his shoulder. There's an owl call and Joey trots past him in the background. Dad sees Albert welcome Joey by the haystacks stroking his nose affectionately. Dad walks on, his expression inscrutable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey trots up a path, pursuing another owl call. After several more calls, he still can't spot Albert, until he cranes his neck up and sees Albert sitting in a nearby tr Albert laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyons is there with his son, David, and his unlikable cronies. He holds a meager handful of cash. Dad and Mum l chastened. The mood is sombre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's only fifteen here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest will come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know by rights I could take this farm back today, don't you? And I'm a great believer in my rights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you drank less beer and bought fewer horses you might be able to look your landlord in the eye, Narracott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyons begins loading up his ledger into his bag. 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I'll pay you. We got to plant the bottom field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bottom field's rock hard. Only stones down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we're going to plow it. Just give me `til the autumn. I'll pay every penny I owe you. With interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you going to plow it? Not with that fancy animal of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll not get that one in a harness, let alone pulling a plow. Even drunk on a Tuesday night, you know that. And I can't wait for the money - there's a war coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad stands up from his chair, resolute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise you that field will be plowed. We'll plant it with turnips. And the money will be yours when harvest comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Narracott interjects, desperate.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: Please, sir. Please. Lyons takes his time. He looks at them both - Ted and Ros almost beaten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well - if that fancy plows that field I'll give you till October to set things straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyons heads for the door, but Albert stands in his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if he doesn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take the horse on the day he fails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'll take your father's farm and give it to working men who can hold their pints and hold their heads high in decent company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyons tries to move past, but Albert grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, please. Sir, you can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now, now, lad. What - are you bladdered as well?! Ted Narracott - I got you down in my book!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert knows he has to back down. Lyons walks past him an leaves with David and his cronies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold the goose attacks Lyons and his men. They quickly pile into his car and drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted stands in the kitchen immobile with upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad throws open the stable door, jerks the harness from t wall, throws open Joey's stall and starts to lunge at the horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert runs in to try to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't harness him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got to be collared. Dad starts to grapple with Joey desperately flailing in a attempt to get the harness onto Joey. Joey is completely confused and frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you can't. Look, you're scaring him, Dad. You're scaring him. He...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't take a plow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey tries to push Dad out of the way, Dad frustrated by hits Joey hard with the harness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got to plow! 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't be able to do it - he's too young - he's not even been backed yet....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey rears up and kicks Dad. Who falls to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: Ted!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert grabs Joey's bridle. Joey wrestles with Albert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright, boy. It's alright. It's alright. It's alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad is mad with anger and frustration - and in pain. He staggers to his feet and leaves. Albert calms Joey down. Mrs. Narracott returns the harnes to its hook.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: I knew this would happen soon as I laid eyes on him....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then she notices Dad has returned. He has a gun.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ted. No. Ted, no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's worth nothing to me! If he won't take the collar, he's not worth a damn thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad? He grabs the rifle, but Dad shoves him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad raises the rifle, but Albert wrestles for it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad. Stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Furious with frustration Dad throws Albert to the ground takes aim at the horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Narracott quickly pulls the gun aside.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: You shoot that horse we have nothing. 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad whips the gun back towards Joey to find Albert standi between them - right in front of the gun's barrel. For a second we think Albert will be inadvertently shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad pauses his finger just in time. Albert gently holds t barrel of the gun. Speaks calmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were right what you said, Dad. "He'll do it," you told Lyons, "He'll plow that field." And he will! You'll see. He'll show you. We'll show you. We'll get it done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad looks at him, frozen. Mrs. Narracott eases the gun aw from him -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let go. Let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and hands it to Albert, telling him -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Albert leaves, Ted takes out his flask. But Rosie take from him gently. He doesn't resist.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: Here, here. Some days are best forgotten. Today ain't one of them. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit the stable together, leaving Joey in his stall.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STABLES. DAWN.
dialogues.text: Albert walks towards the stables - enters. And talks to J as he prepares the harness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you today, Joey? I don't know much about life, boy, but I do know that there are big days and there are small days. And most days are small days, and, well, they don't matter much to anyone - but this - well, this is a big one. This is our big day. Well, it's cold out there. So I'm going to take this off - (he takes off his coat) Well, if it's tough for you - it should be tough for me, too... 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is left in just a loose-fitting white shirt....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I'm gonna teach you how to plow and you're gonna learn. Is that understood? And then we can be together, which is how I believe things are meant to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey instinctively balks, but Albert is stern with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy. Steady, boy. Here we go. Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he approaches Joey with the harness, Harold the goose enters the stable to watch. Albert approaches gently and slowly puts the harness over own neck and shoulders to demonstrate -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, easy... Look at me, Joey. See? See? You've just gotta put your nose through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a moment between them. The horse looks Albert in th eye, then yields. Albert comforts him and show there is nothing to fear. Finally he gets the harness in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. See? You've got it. You've got it. Good boy. There...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold honks his approval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert leads Joey out across the yard, through the broken gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a grey day as they walk across the plowed fields towards the huge lower field. They come to a rusty, primi plow left in the grass. Albert looks around the field - i overgrown, it seems to go on forever - even if Joey was a plow horse this would be a heavy task.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si Easton and Andrew stroll up the road to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too large, too rocky, matted with grass roots. Even a sturdy plow horse'd never manage it alone. 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet he will, I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd swear he'd sprout wings and fly if Albert had told you so. (smiling at his son:) It's a fine thing, loyal to your mate. Even if he is a bit barmy. A team of two might manage, given a month and good weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're interrupted by the honk of a horn as Lyons and Da pull up in a car. Lyons and David get out. Their driver remains inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted too squeamish to watch, is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Course he's watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si nods in the direction of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert steadies Joey and starts to tie on the heavy plow. just seems too big and bulky for Joey's sleek frame. Albe sets Joey right and fixes the plow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyons, David, Si, and Andrew walk towards Dad, who looks anxiously from a nearby hedgerow. Lyons gestures at David stay back and walks over to Ted alone. He stands beside h and begins to talk gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you've raised him up a true Narracott, Ted, picture of his father, he is: not a dollop of ordinary sense but that thick stubbornness that'll lead him to insist on the impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down in the field, Albert continues to prep the plow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't a farmer in Devon didn't admire you, myself among `em, leaving your brothers that fine farm and setting yourself at this stoney patch of unpromising ground. You've fettle enough for twenty men, but with a gimpy leg and the drinking - for the pain, isn't it, that you drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - yeah, none of us could have anticipated an ending better than this. Makes me question the wisdom of the charity that urged me to rent you this place, not only looking at you, me old pal, but that pretty little wife of yours, thought you were a spark, she did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted hasn't acknowledged Lyons for a second; he's never ta his eyes off Albert. He simply stands and walks away as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now your son's sinking into the selfsame bog that's swallowing you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert has been meticulously preparing everything, positioning Joey, checking the tethers, digging the rusty plow in the earth. He takes his position behind the plow, throwing the rear leather harness over his own neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See Joey - I got the collar, too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert gently snaps the reins. Joey doesn't move, confuse the whole affair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, boy. Walk on. That's it. Walk on! Walk on, Joey. Come on, boy, walk on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be better off startin' at the top of the hill and goin' down! Gravity's the only friend you're gonna have today, young lad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walk on, Joey! Walk on! Come on, Joey, walk on. Walk on, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the house, Mrs. Narracott opens an upstairs window to on, anxiously. Ted, standing alone by the fence, only loo at Albert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walk on. Come on, walk on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll take the whip to move him. 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as Ted is saying this, Albert, as if hearing his fat takes a breath and then abruptly produces a whip. Joey's ears prick up. Albert, grimly determined, snaps the whip Joey. Joey panics and bolts. The plow spins to its side, pulls Albert off his feet. Joey drags them all the way to the top of the hill, right by the farmhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyons, yelling, starts laughing and can't stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravo! You've reached the top of the hill! Off you go again, boy! You'll make even better time comin' down!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues past Dad, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT - Mrs. Narracott looks on from the house. He glances back at her. Her face is full of angry concern fo their son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Townsfolk begin arriving, climbing the hill to the lower field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted looks down, ashamed. Mrs. Narracott looks back at Alb mortified, bruised, setting the plow right again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Narracott moves away from the window, takes a seat, picks up her knitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later - Albert has made no progress. Joey is moving, but only in a useless circle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good boy. Good lad. Good lad. Now walk on. Good boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More townsfolk clamor to the fence. Andrew calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albie, we're all with ya!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert tries to encourage him forward but Joey still isn' pulling sufficiently. The plow skips uselessly over the surface stones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look look look! The plow hasn't even cut yet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Albert struggles with the plow, he sees Dad walking up hill behind the spectators. He doesn't even turn to his s 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey strains as Albert pushes with all his might. We sens the strain on the horse and the inappropriateness of the task. But Joey perseveres. The plow limps along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know - I believe we can do it, Joey. I knew when I first saw you that you'd be the best of us. That's why he bought you. He knows you've all the courage he never had. I knew when I first saw you that you'd be the one who'd save us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plow skips and Albert falls. Joey's legs buckle and h goes to his knees. Albert rushes to his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa. Whoa. Lyons calls from the crowd as rain starts to fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got no chance, lad. He'll not turn over half an acre. Give it up now. You've done well. You've tried hard. You're more of a man than your father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert examines the collar - he sees it is ripping into Joey's flesh. He grabs his shirt, tears a piece off it, tenderly folds it and puts it between Joey's shoulder and collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on now, Mr. Lyons, that's a bit rough, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he'll destroy that horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd's beginning to disperse. One of Lyons' cronies holds his umbrella as he returns to his car. He passes Te

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be over Thursday. Give you a day to close it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Narracott emerges from the house and heads to the fe holding her knitting in the rain, ignoring the leaving crowds. A SYMPATHETIC NEIGHBOR hands her: 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your wool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyons passes behind her, almost speaks, but then thinks better of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the rain intensifies, Albert digs his toe into the wet soil and notices how it has softened. Suddenly something flashes through Albert's mind. He leaps into action, runs through the rain to shout at Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, boy! You've got to do it, Joey. You don't know, so I'm gonna have to do the knowing for you when the rest of our lives depend on this! So get set to pull - and pull straight! And pull hard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He races back to the plow and sets himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, boy! Go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey pulls firmly and finally the inertia is broken - the rain has softened the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walk on, Joey! Walk on! That's it! Good boy, Joey! Good boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, the plow bites deep into the soil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walk on! Walk on! Walk on! Walk on, Joey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the fence, Mrs. Narracott looks on in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert notices a large rock in their path. Andrew sees it too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go around it!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, Joey! Whoa, Joey! Joey! Joey, whoa whoa whoa! Joey, stop! You'll break the blade - 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert hauls back on the reins, but Joey throws his flank forward, straining and lurching until the plow blade spli the rock completely in half and now the plow moves more easily through the wet ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ground yields. Soon Albert and Joey are making great progress. The wet earth slipping open beneath them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew is loving it, speaks in wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you look at you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Narracott looks very happy, a smile breaking slowly across her face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd begins to return. Lyons notices and looks out f his car - sees the plow digging through the field. Annoyed at the progress Albert's making, he gets out of h car and walks over to Mrs. Narracott. With great disdain

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd not let a child of mine slip in the mud alongside a plow blade. He could lose a foot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Narracott brandishes her knitting needles, backing h up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll likelier lose an eye, Mr. Lyons, if you carry on prating at me how to manage my son! Or my plow, or my horse, or my field, or my farm! Dad sits nearby, watching this exchange with silent appro Lyons stares at her, gape-mouthed, as she turns her atten back to Albert.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: Come on, Albie! Push on through!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain becomes torrential. Lyons turns towards the car gestures, frustrated, to his driver, who runs forward wit the umbrella to shield his boss from the rain. David rema on the running board, watching Albert plowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plow speeds through the earth. The boy and the horse working as one. It is a moment of triumph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get it done, Albie! Get it done! 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull back to see they have made only the smallest dent the enormous field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Lyons' car passes, Dad steps forward, takes in the sce and almost smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain has abated. Albert, soaked to the skin, sits nex to Joey. They are both covered in mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew, followed by Si Easton, charges through the gate u Albert. They are lifting Albert up between them, laughing Si Easton planting a kiss on Albert's muddy cheek, Andrew tousling his filthy hair, when Mrs. Narracott arrives wit Ted. She helps Si and Andrew lift Albert and slings her son's arm over her shoulder, glowing with pride, crying, overjoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my pair of fools. My mighty fools.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the others help Albert up, Ted tends to Joey. He looks over to his son and, after a moment, removes his cap and slightly bows his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others stagger away, supporting Albert, and Ted pats horse and gently begins to unbuckle the harness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert washes Joey and tends the wounds and sores on his body. Rosie is putting antiseptic on Albert's wrists and shoulders. Joey bristles but is soothed by Albert's care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're as battered and bloodied as he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where's Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still in the bottom field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stumbling about, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the drink, Albert, that makes him stumble - 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drinks, mum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, so might you if you'd been where he's been, seen what he's seen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he don't talk to me about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't talk about it because he can't. There aren't words for some things. Come here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosie stalks over to a pile of broken equipment in a corn of the stables. She rummages until she finds a waterstain brown paper parcel tied with yarn. She brushes away some mouse turds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mice've been at it. Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit together on a step. As she begins to untie the yarn, a change comes over her: her irritated determinatio gives way to sadness. Albert comes to her and kneels besi her as she gently opens the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside there's a red and tan pennant, knotted and fringed both ends.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: Here. It's his campaign pennant. He were Sergeant, Seventh Battalion, Imperial Yeomanry. Then with great care she unfolds the sash to reveal two silver medals. The first, with the profile of Victoria, h from a red, blue and orange ribbon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that is the Queen's South Africa Medal. Every man who fought in the Boer War got one of those. But this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds up the other medal, hanging from a red and blac ribbon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the Distinguished Conduct Medal. 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands Albert the Distinguished Conduct Medal. He take it, astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not dad's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it ain't mine, dear. He got that after the fighting at Transvaal. After he'd been hurt, and he'd saved some other lads, and well... I don't know what else, he won't tell me either. But the first day he got home he just... tossed them out. First day he could walk, he threw `em straight in the dustbin, and wouldn't hear a word I said not to. Albert nods, looking at the medal and campaign pennant. S takes the medal back, puts it in the sash, and begins to it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, what you done today, you and Joey, you're chuffed up now, and so you should be, my splendid boy. It's good to be proud when you done something good. But what he done, in Africa, whatever it was, he takes no pride in it. Hard as it surely was, and however much pain it's cost him, he refuses to be proud of killing, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She returns the things in the footlocker, closes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be proud. If I'd gone off to war. If I'd gone and saved my mates, and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, whether or not you think you'd do the same thing as him... Think how brave he is for refusing to be proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She heads back to Albert, pennant in hand. 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, your dad makes mistakes. And he drinks to forget the mistakes that he's made - but he never gave up and he does that for us. And today, you showed the world it's all been worth it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she leaves, she drapes the pennant over Albert's shoul

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep looking after Joey and he'll always be looking after you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert looks again at the pennant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant, Seventh Battalion, Imperial Yeomanry. (amazed, to Joey:) You see this, Joey? It's been through an entire war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert holds the pennant in wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not stealing it. I'll give it back to him, someday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early morning. Dad hobbling across the furrows, alone, planting the field by hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert and Joey are now in a meadow. They trot past the f he plowed, now packed with a strong and sturdy crop, whic Ted tends to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is breaking through and Joey starts to run across field and up a small incline. As both Joey and Albert gai confidence they pick up speed. Albert pushes Joey on, the are going faster and faster, Albert yells with the exhilaration of it all. Joey races flat out across the countryside. Albert hanging on for dear life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert and Joey pull up beside a sleek red car. It's Lyon car, being driven by David Lyons, every inch the expensiv tailored rural gentry. 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, I'm the only boy that drives in the village. No one else drives but me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right and this is my dad's car. You're lucky that you're in it. I'm not normally allowed to drive it `cause it's so -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert urges Joey to go faster, till they're neck and nec beside the car, racing it. David Lyons looks to see Alber and Joey running alongside his car. He feigns disinterest Albert glances at David, but he's much more interested in very pretty young woman seated next to David, her hands trying to control her hair, flying in the wind. Forgettin himself momentarily, Albert stares at her, dazzled. The w turns to David:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he a friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles at Albert, encouraging him. David Lyons, annoy pushes the accelerator down, and the car edges ahead of J

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not for long. The sound of the acceleration and Alber eagerness to impress the young woman make Joey go faster, again he moves out ahead of the car. The young woman grin at Albert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up ahead Albert sees that the wall alongside of which he' been racing turns the corner, presenting him and Joey wit obstacle. Albert encourages Joey to go faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, boy, let's show her how to fly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They head right for the wall, but at the very last moment Joey balks and comes to a dead standstill, sending Albert sailing over the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the car, the girl gasps and covers her mouth, concerned. David says nothing, but allows himself a small smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other side of the wall, Albert stands a bit batter but unfazed. 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...you're clearly not gonna be a jumper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thunder starts to rumble ominously in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert and Joey return, driving sheep before them. Angry storm clouds stretch to the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Albert leads Joey to the stable, lighting blasts acros angry sky. The rain is falling in torrents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another crack of thunder - and a piece of wood in the roo gives way - water gushes in - Dad rushes to support the r as the wind forces a window open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment, the door suddenly swings open with the violence of the storm, smashing against the wall - Dad an Rosie turn - and there is Harold the goose, who scuttles without his usual arrogance and hides himself in a corner

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: Shoo, Harold. Shoo, shoo, shoo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thunder cracks again and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert and Dad walk across the field. Mrs. Narracott digs through the mess. The entire crop is flat - ruined by the storms. The ground squelches beneath their feet. The whole field is a write off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can try planting something else, or we could hire ourselves out to Uncle Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad doesn't answer. He shakes his head and limps away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How else we gonna pay Mr. Lyons' rent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted doesn't turn around. 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Narracott makes some coffee. Ted sits alone on a cha

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NARRACOTT
dialogues.text: What we gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to believe that God gave each man his fair portion of bad luck. I don't feel that any more. I've had more than my share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll stop loving me, Rose. And I won't blame you when you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I might hate you more - but I'll never love you less. Then somewhere in the distance, an unfamiliar sound...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A motorbike rumbles along the lane at huge speed creating cloud of dust as it goes. The noise of the motorbike is drawing attention from all over the valley. It can be hea fields away and everyone is drawn to this completely unhe of sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The motorbike whizzes through the village. Heads turn in astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's war! The bike comes to a stop in the market place. The rider t off his goggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men of the village start to flock around the machine, wit great curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORBIKE RIDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We are at War with Germany. You hear? England is at war with Germany.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shock and amazement. The rider takes off his goggles:

dialogues.speaker: MOTORBIKE RIDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They're going to ring the bells at six o'clock - and then never ring them again until the war is over. 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone across England knows that their lives are about change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn rises over the farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert races to the stables, excited with the campaign pennant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Albert enters the stables, he calls out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look smart, Joey lad, it's the Tavistock Fair!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert opens the doors and stops dead. He looks at the em stables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rushes into the kitchen. His mother stares out the win She has been crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What has he done with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says nothing, but her face gives everything away. Alb in a panic turns and runs out into the lane. Mrs. Narraco tears up again. EXT. SQUARE OF A MARKET TOWN. THE SAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The market square is full of military men. The Union Jack flying up the flagpole. A group of girls has gathered to check out the army boys. Eager young men crowd a table staffed by recruiting officers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last name first. First name, middle name, last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAPTAIN NICHOLLS is in the square inspecting Joey, knowledgably. He is a handsome, attractive, modest, upper class man. Dad stands beside him. He checks Joey's teeth, feet and finally, looks him straight in the eye. 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take my word for it - finest horse in the parish. Goes like a racer, strong, decent, very fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Nicholls has immediately connected with Joey and him at his ease. SAM PERKINS, a tough sergeant, is physic inspecting Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No curbs, no splints, good feet and teeth. He's as sound as a bell, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how much are you charging, sir - for this strong, decent, and very fine animal?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you twenty and not a penny more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty is no good to me, Captain. Thirty five and he's yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even know how he rides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he rides... Splendidly. You'll be astonished. I promise you that. (his heart's in his throat, fighting back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finest horse in all of Devon. Finest horse I ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert bursts into the square just in time to see Nicholl and Dad shake hands. Their business concluded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert races towards Joey. Ted grabs him. Albert fights t get free. He looks at his father in anger and betrayal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't! You can't, he's mine! I trained him! 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert is hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't have him. He's my horse, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it's too late, lad. I've just paid thirty guineas for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, I'll get you money. I will, I'll get you money. I'll...I'll work for it! I'll work for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't obey anyone else. He won't be any good in the war, neither. He...he shies at every sound!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert snaps to attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if Joey's going, I'm going, too. I'm volunteering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. What's your name, lad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how old are you, Albert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nineteen, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir. But, but I look nineteen and I'm bigger than most nineteen-year- olds, sir! And I'm strong, sir! And I...I'm not afraid of anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't doubt your qualifications, Albert, but the law is very clear about the proper age for soldiering, and your father's done what he had to do. You know that. Thirty guineas isn't nearly enough to purchase a horse as fine as your Joey, I know that. But it's all I've got. Will you lease him to me, Albert, to be my own mount? (he removes his cap,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise you, man to man, that I'll look after him as closely as you've done, I'll respect him and all the care that you've taken with him. And if I can - I'll return him to your care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert looks at him. Although Nicholls speaks with author he has a kindness which Albert recognizes.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN NICHOLLS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now say goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert kisses Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, boy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But at that moment, Sam Perkins pulls Joey away:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, turn it in, eh? That's enough. He's a horse, not a dog. Now, on your way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholls walks away into the crowd. The Sergeant pulls Jo but Joey does not want to be separated from Albert. His reaction is implacable, reminiscent to the separation fro his mother. Perkins leads Joey away. They disappear into crowd and Rosie is suddenly there. Ted senses her silent judgment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to lose the farm, Rose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the way you did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we're at war. 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't we just.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at Albert. Implacable. Forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The recruits march through town under pennants and the strains of a familiar song("The Jolly Plowboy") - it is a song they all know, which means a lot to them - full of s a song of harvest or a Celtic hymn, something relating specifically to the lives they have led together. Everyon every age - everyone in the village knows this song - it theirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholls passes in his car and we see those they are leav behind - cheering - a whole generation of young men is marching off to war. One girlfriend rushes up to kiss her leaving boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert watches Joey, then remembers the campaign pennant dangling from his pocket. He runs up to Joey -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and tucks the pennant into Joey's halter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here now, I've told you - sling your hook!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Nicholls intervenes from his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him be, Perkins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't the end. This isn't the end, my brother... I, Albert Narracott, solemnly swear we will be together again. Wherever you are, I will find you. And I will bring you home!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then they are past him, leaving him behind. As Perkin leads Joey across a stone bridge, Albert watches from the bank of the stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey balks one last time - 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa. Steady, steady. Steady now, come on. Walk on! Walk on now, come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - then Perkins leads him away, leaving Albert behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The very last recruits leave the village - leaving the de of this army's visit strewn on the square. Like the debri of a party you are already beginning to regret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey is handed off to a groom. Joey is amazed by the scal of the building. Each horse has a large stall and is bein tended to assiduously. Joey looks around at the hundreds men and horses around him and panics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa whoa whoa. Easy easy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bucks, throwing the groom to the ground, and gallops a But Perkins cuts him off, grabs his halter, and jerks him back to attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa whoa whoa, Joey! Stop muckin' about, you hear? Yer in the army now, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes him into his stall, next to Major Stewart's hor a magnificent black stallion, TOPTHORN.

dialogues.speaker: SAM PERKINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good boy, good boy. Steady steady... Easy. Relax. Easy easy, back up. Joey rears up in his stall.

dialogues.speaker: SAM PERKINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Joey - meet Topthorn. Topthorn - this is Joey. Sort out who's in charge between the two of you, you hear? If you want to fight, you get it over with - `cause once we're over there, you're gonna need everything you've got for Fritz!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the first time that Joey has had to deal with ano horse since his mother - the beginning of one of the most important relationships in his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gently, Perkins. I don't want to sour him. 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholls passes his gloves and crop to his bat boy who is there to assist him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There'll be nothing gentle about the war, sir. And there'll be nothing gentle about this one either!

dialogues.speaker: SAM PERKINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I understand that, Sergeant, but I want him fit and shining. He's my horse.

dialogues.speaker: SAM PERKINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholls is joined by his friend LIEUTENANT CHARLIE WAVER He is sweet and friendly - upper class but completely ben

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scares the living daylights out of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perkins. Glad he's on our side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're both joined by a tall, confident officer, MAJOR J STEWART. He sizes up Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad. Not bad at all. Still not a patch on my Topthorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be so sure. I think he's got potential. He's certainly got the bit between his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I actually think my Blenheim is faster than the pair of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly turns from the joking into the efficient seni officer he is. 39.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR STEWART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All right, gentlemen, listen here. Everything tells us the same story, from Waterloo to Omdurman, from Pickett's Charge to the Battle of Mars La Tours - the first attack can and should be the decisive one. Perkins...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No excuses, no mistakes - every horse groomed and fit for presentation! I want a full practice charge tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole regiment is gathered. Everybody is in their ceremonial uniform. It all has the feeling of the Changin the Guard rather than anything related to a real battle. day is hot, the plains are quiet and beautiful, the gathe is huge, there is a real sense of pride and anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Nicholls, resplendent in full uniform rides Joey over the vast expanse of the plain. Both Nicholls and Joe are dressed up like something from the last century, out the Boer War, even the Charge of the Light Brigade. Nicho is proud and confident. They gather before hundreds of me and horses all lined up to be inspected. Charlie joins th looking pretty good on Blenheim. Finally, Nicholls and Charlie reach Stewart and Topthorn waiting in position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought you two had bottled out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholls looks at his friend tolerantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then, let's see what you two jokers are made of, shall we? 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what quiet confidence looks like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wait for you two at the Duke of York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholls and Stewart and Charlie prepare themselves for t charge. Joey and Topthorn size up to one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over to you, Captain Nicholls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Topthorn bristles at Joey. Everyone is highly charged. Th competition between Stewart and Nicholls seems to have be absorbed between the horses. Topthorn and Joey square up the practice charge like two athletes before a race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Draw...swords!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholls raises his sword. It glints in the summer air. I seems to hang there forever. Every man follows suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Topthorn and Joey glance at each other, ready to charge.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN NICHOLLS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Give...point!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every sword is pointed directly ahead at arm's length.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN NICHOLLS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Charge!!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A roar goes up from the men and a deafening pounding of hooves breaks the silence. The huge line of horses start running straight ahead of them. Joey and Topthorn run off top speed. Dust and earth rise up behind them. Bugles, the deafening thunder of hooves. It is exhilarati We see the scale of the operation, we enjoy the speed and splendor of the mass of men and horses. The soldiers shou glee and excitement. Each man pushes his horse to out-run those around him, Nicholls and Stewart seem locked in mor combat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholls smiles at Stewart, confidently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Topthorn starts to pull away, ahead of all the other hors in the line. Nicholls pushes Joey on. Topthorn seems too strong, Joey will never catch them. Nicholls is determine not to be beaten. 41.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN NICHOLLS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, Joey. I know you've got it. Come on, boy! Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes Joey on. Joey digs in and finds hidden strength speed. He starts to catch up with Topthorn and draws alon side. Nicholls and Stewart exchange tense looks.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN NICHOLLS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stewart is amazed and pushes Topthorn harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now both riders are going at their top speed. They are ne and neck - they fight for every inch of advantage, every fibre of their being invested in the race. Nicholls pushe Joey on and Joey pulls away. Joey inches forward till he almost a length ahead of Topthorn. The effort is enormous Nicholls looks back at Stewart, very happy. Stewart's frustration shows. He knows he is beaten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then suddenly they race over the line. Nicholls spears a decorated with a blue ribbon and pulls Joey to a halt. Th have crossed the enemy line. Nicholls is ecstatic. Toptho comes to Joey's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa. Whoa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholls laughs, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice of you to turn up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horses are nose to nose, snorting, we sense the heat, exertion. Topthorn and Joey are brought together by the effort. We sense Topthorn's newly minted respect for Joey And Joey is no soft touch - he slightly holds his head up victory, letting Topthorn know that he knows he won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other horses come charging in. There is a real sense achievement and congratulation amongst the regiment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got speed...I'll give him that. But has he got stamina?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men enjoy the moment of rivalry and the exhilarat of it all. The two horses, face to face rub against each other for the first time. A bond has been formed... 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stewart enters. A phonograph plays "Roses of Picardy." Th walls are decorated with etchings of famous battles, and large map of Western Europe that depicts how the English troops are crossing the channel to confront the Germans n Belgium. Nicholls is writing a letter - though actually a this moment, he is making a little pencil drawing of Joey enclose with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm writing a letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a picture in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's to the boy who owned Joey. I want to show him how wonderful he's looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before we take him away across the Channel to face a million Germans guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Before that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4 a.m. start tomorrow - travelling with the Dragoon Guards and the Royals. Transport detachment - they'll need to be at the docks at 5 am. Check all kit. Battle orders: no polishing - buttons, helmet buckles, stirrup irons - let `em all go dull. I want nothing to flash in the sun and give us away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stewart leaves, he passes Charlie. He casually acknowledges him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie. 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie checks his new cap in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think of the cap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shows the bright red lining to Nicholls.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE WAVERLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Silk lining. I quite like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure it's going to make a lot of difference to the Germans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know about that. Think about it - you're a Boche, just working out which of two chaps to shoot - and you thought - "Good Lord - one of them really is wearing a very stylish cap indeed!" You might shoot the other one instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or, alternatively, think - "I fancy that cap" and kill you first of all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Charlie removes the cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hadn't thought of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholls returns to his sketch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three hundred horses and their charges in a slow march in middle of the most pristine French countryside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholls and Stewart and Charlie ride on a smooth road pa series of posts screened with cloth. They're silhouetted against the setting sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The regiment are tense and nervous as they gingerly make their way along the country road. Topthorn and Joey sense the grim change of atmosphere. 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are in woodland above a plain stretching for miles. small table has been taken out for Stewart and his office SERGEANT MAJOR SINGH - a turbaned Indian with a magnifice moustache dressed in ceremonial garb - explains the lines battle on a map.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. MAJOR SINGH
dialogues.text: That is our target - the German 11th Division - at the moment bivouacked three miles to the east of the Menin Road. We have been watching them and they have pitched tents for the night and lit cooking fires. Knock them out - and we could slide in behind the German lines and come at them from the South at Geluveld.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Numbers?

dialogues.speaker: SGT. MAJOR SINGH
dialogues.text: About six hundred. Infantry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twice our size...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In regiments of horse and men, the advantage is ours.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. MAJOR SINGH
dialogues.text: And we have surprise on our side. But the sooner we move, the better - we have no assurance they'll still be there tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our officers just have a second to take in the news. The has suddenly arrived. The day they have worked for, for s long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Good. So - today it is. Charlie - tell the men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salisbury formation? 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salisbury formation. We'll charge through them and secure the ground behind.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. MAJOR SINGH
dialogues.text: The grass to the left is taller than we are - it's perfect cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent work, Sergeant Major. Time spent on reconnaissance is rarely wasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stewart departs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Singh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholls catches up to Stewart, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN NICHOLLS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They have no idea we're coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not having scruples, are you, Jim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I understand the surprise is everything. But if it must be done, let's do it quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholls notices Charlie nervously attending his horse.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN NICHOLLS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you alright, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never been better. Literally, never better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We worry for him - he is afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stewart rides through the lines astride Topthorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prepare to mount! Mount!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the cry is echoed throughout the regiment, Nicholls accepts Joey from an attending soldier. 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Standley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Joey. My bonny boy. You're all right, aren't you, Joey? Hey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholls takes the red campaign pennant from his pocket a threads it through Joey's reins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
