dialogues.text: Minutes later - Stewart addresses the men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentleman. It is an honour to ride beside you. Make the Kaiser rue the day he dared to cross swords with us. Let every man make himself, his King, his country, and his fallen comrades proud! Be brave. Fear God. Honor the King!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in unison shout) Fear God. Honor the King!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut to an elegant field of tall grass, waving in the gent breeze. Then suddenly three hundred men seem to rise out it. They are in fact our soldiers, mounting their horses but the horses are invisible in the height of the grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stewart gives a signal. We see the intense anticipation o his face. He takes out his sabre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Draw swords! The men draw their sabres in silence. The birds chirping, oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Nicholls just turns to his two friends and almost whispers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, my friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pats Joey's side. And then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forward, to walk! Walk...march!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The regiment begins moving through the field. 47.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR STEWART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Forward to canter! Canter...march!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men start to float over the grass - swept along by th invisible horses, until...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly they emerge from the tall grass - the immense po of the galloping horses - silence explodes into a violent crashing of hooves. The noise is immense, swords are flyi in the air. Hundreds of horses racing towards the German encampment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the German side, TWO SOLDIERS wake to the sound of hoofbeats. They pull their tent flap aside to find the invincible charge coming towards them. The Germans are totally unprepared. We see them scramble back towards ten rush towards their guns - one man pulling up his trousers rushes for cover. One German drops some dirty dishes into wash pot, screaming:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kavallerie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Topthorn and Joey race each other like a rerun of their practice on Salisbury Plain. The swords and uniforms glin the sun, the German troops look terrified - some run in panic, others prepare to stand their ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The British head in for the kill, the men scream battle c with sheer exhilaration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the horses at close quarters running with all thei might. Nicholls and Stewart yell as they approach the ene The surprise attack is a huge success. The first row of unprepared Germans are falling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The regiment sweeps through the encampment, cutting down soldiers and driving the rest in a panicked retreat to th tree line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then we see, in the shadows of the forest behind the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A machine gun. No, a line of machine guns - at least twen guns, sandbagged apart - the logical, new, modern defence a garrison. In an instant, the fleeing Germans have manne the guns. All now firing. 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The noise of the blast of bullets drowns out everything e A score of men and horses are suddenly on the ground, it happens almost so quickly Joey and Topthorn don't realize anything's wrong and find themselves racing straight towa the guns. The bullets keep coming, now suddenly half of t regiment are on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horse after horse races past the guns into the woods...al them now riderless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholls watches helplessly as one of the barrels swings towards him. His face goes slack as he realizes he is abo to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment later, Joey runs on - we pan up to see he is run on riderless - he has not realized that Nicholls is gone. bullets whizz around his head, but he still runs directly ahead. We would always know him by the red pennant Nichol tied on his saddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey is now running through the German lines. No one both to attack him as the German's concentrate their efforts o the cavalry behind him. The line of machine guns fire as decimating the horses and their riders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey leaps and dances nimbly through the German ranks, bu suddenly rears up in the confusion, surrounded by Germans

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near him, surviving English officers are hauled from thei horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stewart wheels back around on Topthorn, sabre in hand. Bu he, too, is quickly surrounded by several Germans with th rifles trained on him. A furious GERMAN OFFICER storms ov speaks perfect English:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Did you think that a garrison on open ground would go undefended? Look at yourself! Who do you think you are?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stewart looks at the Officer - at the guns that surround and throws down his sabre, stabbing it into the ground. T Germans take Stewart from Topthorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around them, the fields are littered with dead soldiers a horses. 49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Topthorn appears disoriented and frightened. Suddenly, he rears up and bolts from his new German handler, galloping over to Joey. The horses briefly nuzzle, but both rear up again as they are separated and led past a young German soldier, GUNTHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He zeroes in on them, the finest horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slightly more JUNIOR OFFICER approaches the outraged se officer.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR GERMAN OFFICER.
dialogues.text: What do we do with the horses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they're injured, shoot them.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR GERMAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: And the others, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others you round up and take to base camp - they will pull guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never get fancy horses like these to pull guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then shoot them also.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunther, the young private, now standing behind them, interjects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir - perhaps we could use some of them with the ambulances - to get the injured men off the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will they take the harness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to try, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officers move away - that's enough talk about horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT ON - Gunther is now with Joey and Topthorn. Near a wo ambulance - which is like a giant wagon to carry humans. is with MICHAEL, a very young soldier, his brother - poss as young as 14. 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunther lifts a heavy pulling harness - and tries to get Topthorn into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't work - they're cavalry

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't get the harness on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Topthorn balks violently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa. Easy, now, easy now, Englishman... Whoa, whoa, whoa. Easy now, easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunther! It's hopeless - we can't help them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And suddenly Joey moves up and presents himself, with his strange self assurance and self sacrifice. And instinct f survival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sniffs the harness and places his head through it, whi helps to calm Topthorn enough that Gunther can slip the collar onto the big black horse. Gunther turns to Joey, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well, look at you. Whoever taught you this has just saved your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunther spots the red ribbon in Joey's saddle, removes it folds it, and places it in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later - Gunther and Michael are returning from the battlefield with Topthorn and Joey, pulling an ambulance British and German wounded. Amongst the wounded, we see a hand gripping a battered, silk lined hat. It is Waverly, wounded but alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si Easton lets himself in through the gate. Ted pulls up turnips from their three acre crop. 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosie, just across a furrow, is also engaged in the harve It's hard work. Si holds a parcel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello the farm!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up, wiping her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Si Easton!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert passes carrying a crate laden with turnips, but pu up short when he hears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was at the post office and while I was there, Mrs. Allen said a parcel had come for Albert, from the, from the, from over there - and I thought I could go up that way in the morning. And - here it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, who'd be sending me a parcel over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, open it and see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert opens the parcel and pulls out a leather sketchboo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a sketchbook... (gasp of realization) That's Captain Nicholls' sketchbook! See that? That's a picture of Joey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a picture of Joey. Well, I never!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there's a letter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, go on then, go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear Albert Narracott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Nicholls, who died...Captain Nicholls, who died in action today left you this. Yours, Sergeant Sam Perkins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si Easton drops his head guiltily. Rosie catches this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't to know it was bad news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was riding Joey when he died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know that he was riding him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "In action," it says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody falls silent. Albert goes to the fence and look down at the sketches of Joey. Rosie looks at her son, her heart breaking for him. Dad returns to the harvest withou word. Albert looks off to the horizon and - over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE -- A step stool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael mounts the stool next to Joey and Topthorn, remov their harnesses and carries them across the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael slips and falls into the mud. Gunther dashes over and pulls him up just before a military convoy pulls into camp, running over the tack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BASE CAMP OFFICER appears on a motorbike. BASE CAMP OFFICER. Gentlemen! We move forward to the frontline tonight. Full marching orders. Get moving!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the soldiers hop to their orders, the officer turns to

dialogues.speaker: BASE CAMP OFFICER
dialogues.text: Schroeder! Schroeder!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Michael and Gunther turn to him. But it's Gunther th Officer wants to talk to.

dialogues.speaker: BASE CAMP OFFICER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, not you - you. Come. 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunther picks up the dropped harnesses as he approaches.

dialogues.speaker: BASE CAMP OFFICER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm keeping you here. You are best with the horses and we need to move the camp quickly if the enemy continue to push through from the west.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're pushing through?

dialogues.speaker: BASE CAMP OFFICER
dialogues.text: I'm told. We will move later when we find where the horses are needed most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Perhaps I can keep my brother here with me, he's also very good with horses.

dialogues.speaker: BASE CAMP OFFICER
dialogues.text: Oh no no. Not necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get moving. We leave tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks away. Gunther is stricken by the news, but Micha is excited. As he leads Joey past his brother:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, Gunther.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunther can't really speak. Michael is just a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soldiers are lifting up their equipment - gathering - mov in the same direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a quiet tent, a few last soldiers are packing. And the are Gunther and Michael, packing together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not going. I'll tell them you are only fourteen, that you're a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father signed me in. He knew my age -and so do they. 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The process of packing is their way of coping with the sh Gunther is folding one of Michael's shirts. Michael takes back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother obviously never taught you how to fold a shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course she did. I just wasn't listening. But you need to listen now! I promised her, I made her a solemn promise, that you would be safe with me. With me, Michael!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans close to Michael, talking in almost a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll never make a head count. There are too many of us. You can stay here - slip underneath the bed - until they move out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael carries on with his packing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunther, it will be fine. And when all the machines break down and they call up the horses, I'll see you at the front. We'll be together again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now the case is packed. Gunther heads to the tent opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunther...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking round, the tent is now empty. The moment to leave come. Gunther pulls the red pennant from his pocket and follows Michael out of the tent to where the soldiers are lining up in the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm giving this to you. For luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunther ties the pennant to the back of Michael's pack as forms up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To keep you safe. 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael smiles at him and begins to march. Marching towar Ypres, on the Western Front.

dialogues.speaker: BASE CAMP OFFICER
dialogues.text: Im schnellschritt! Marsch...links! Zwei, drei, vier!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We settle on young Michael - in line - he passes Gunther. remains eager. But it is goodbye. These soldiers moving i the darkness and towards death. Gunther looks on - tears his eyes. The two horses are uneasy - sensing tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few minutes later - Gunther grabs a saddle and throws i onto Joey's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to the soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly we see the galloping legs of two horses. They wh past the back of the line of marching soldiers. It's clea what is happening - Gunther is on Topthorn - and has hold Joey, on a loose rope, galloping beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunther, galloping along the line of soldiers, spots what is looking for, a red pennant unfurled and flapping in th wind, tied onto Michael's pack. Gunther speeds toward him This was his plan all along. And in an instant he is besi him and without Michael ever realizing, he suddenly finds arms and legs akimbo, as he is yanked out of the line and dragged along the ground, desperately close to Joey's pounding hooves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael looks at the soldiers beside him - he looks at th skyline of violence ahead...but before he can decide, he feels his brother's arm - pulling him upwards. And now, t two of them are fully on Topthorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They leave a jumble of soldiers in their wake as the offi try to restore order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back in line! Line!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael now rides Joey, following Gunther on Topthorn. Th brothers look at each other - can't believe what they hav done - Michael is following his brother, swept along, doe know if it is right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Michael and Joey and Gunther and Topthorn charge on t freedom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They spot a lonely house and burst past a line with some drying clothes. 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they ride, they grab civilian shirts and jackets and trousers, the clothes pegs pinging off and falling to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And on they ride - though all too soon day starts to brea the far distance. They see a very dilapidated windmill. T aim for it as the sun begins to seriously break over the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach the windmill. It feels very unused. The machin of the windmill creaks in the dawn. The brothers untether horses, careful now that it is light outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hungry. Did you bring food?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael fingers the pennant on Joey's reins. Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will Father be ashamed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will pretend to be. Maybe at first he will be. But in the end, he will be glad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And us? What about us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunther looks at him - but doesn't reply. As Michael remo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was ready to go. I was proud to go. (after a beat, in a very

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later - They sit in silence, waiting for sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The food in Italy is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the women? 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as good as the food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because...they've eaten too much of the food?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are too young for war. And you're too young for women!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunther laughingly pushes him over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel so young. Not anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to sleep - we have a big night of riding ahead. Goodnight, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jokingly strokes Michael's cheek. Michael swats him aw but as he settles in the hay:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night night, Gunther.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunther and Michael sleep. Suddenly something awakens Joe He stirs and then rises. Hear the sound of engines and se lights through the slats sweeping across Joey's face. Michael and Gunther are stirring in their sleep as we hea car and several motorcycles approaching. Head-lamps filte through the cracks in the windmill walls stabbing the brothers awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hei! In die windmhle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys spring up, speaking in terrified whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, go, go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They race up a nearby ladder, but Michael stumbles agains table, upsetting some gear. It clatters loudly. They cowe as they hear boots tromping up the steps outside. Then th windmill doors are thrown open, pinning them in the brigh headlights of the vehicles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they're marched out, we see what they see: A German ca two motorcycles. Six Germans, including the officer who w in charge of them.

dialogues.speaker: BASE CAMP OFFICER
dialogues.text: Schroeder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BASE CAMP OFFICER
dialogues.text: A mistake? He's offering an excuse, but -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officer accepts this grimly, nods.

dialogues.speaker: BASE CAMP OFFICER
dialogues.text: Ja...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the boys are taken away, he lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the turning arms of the windmill, we glimpse the double execution. Four rifles fire - flashes of the soldi shooting - the bodies on the ground. EXT. OUTSIDE THE WINDMILL. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Complete stillness in the empty countryside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are Joey and Topthorn, still waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then suddenly - the doors of the windmill creak. The horses turn, immensely aware of the break in the silence. door opens a little - and we see, reflected in Joey's eye very delicate, beautiful, thirteen-year-old country girl (EMILIE).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at the horses. They stare straight back at her And she walks straight out again, closing the big door be her. Joey and Topthorn settle for a moment. 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time transition - Joey and Topthorn are in a slightly different place - and the door opens again. It is the sam little girl - but this time she comes in carrying two buc full of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small humble farmhouse - and round it, small fields, planted with different fruit crops. We see an old man (GRANDFATHER), burdened with a basket of berries heading towards the farmhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SOUND CAUSES HIM TO LOOK OUT ACROSS THE FARM -- far in distance the STORM OF WAR is in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters the kitchen - which is rough, but full of the paraphernalia of jam-making - jars, sieves, pectin, sugar Emilie is at the sink, washing berries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads towards the side-board, dumps the two bags and l the first handful of fruits on to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She empties her clean berries into a bowl. Notes the explosions outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's closer today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind plays tricks with the noise - it's moving away from us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can hear it, Grandpre, and there is no wind. You shouldn't lie to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. There is no wind here. But over there - a wind so strong it will lift you off the ground...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lie about everything. You say you aren't worried but it's clear you are. I know the war is approaching but you say, "Oh, it's just a trick of the wind."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He retrieves a bottle of medicine from the mantle. 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You started lying when Mama and Papa went away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pours a load of sugar into a bowl with the fruit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're dead. But you won't say so. Do you think I'll die if you tell me the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth is - He feeds her a spoonful of the medicine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - you should speak to your elders with respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sticks her wet finger in the sugar and sucks it to he with the taste of the medicine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you tell me the truth about the war, I will tell you the truth about the big horses I've been keeping in the windmill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing, putting his hands on his hips) Now - who is the one telling lies! EXT. COURTYARD. SAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandfather looks stunned as he paces in front of JOEY AN TOPTHORN - who stand in the small courtyard outside the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the windmill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. They were standing in the windmill waiting for Don Quixote. This is Franois (Joey) and this is Claude (Topthorn). 61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I named them after two boys who broke my heart last Summer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must belong to someone. Horses like this don't just appear from a fairy-tale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes - I know, Grandpre. They are not unicorns - so I will be fair and wait -- one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie... Emilie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if no one comes to get them by night-time, then they belong to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie. Look at me. You cannot ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother used to tell me how my bones would give way with the slightest bump or fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. That's right. So it is settled? She kisses his cheek --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- but then calmly leads the horses back to the windmill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will only be settled when I decide which one to ride first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's - Over my dead body!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least I won't have long to wait. 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is the end of the conversation as far as she is concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie is with the horses in the little stable at the end the courtyard - a bit away from the farm house - she is feeding them out of a bucket - not very nice gruel.... WE SEE THAT SHE IS HESITANT WITH THEM - that she has spent n time around horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in love with a boy called Franois - who had your lovely eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately he was in love with a girl called Marie, who had your teeth. She fell for a boy called Claude - who broke my heart. And who I intend to marry one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandfather watches Emilie from inside the house as he ma jam.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Eyes on me. No talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, Emilie has fashioned two jumps. The big one for and a little demonstration obstacle for herself. She lead Joey to a starting point about 30 yards in front of some crates supporting a stick about four feet off the ground. The red pennant hangs from the stick. Joey stands quietly Emilie hobbles to the big jump, making a jumping gesture her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today we learn to jump. Did you know the French cleared one meter eighty- five at the Paris Olympics to win the gold medal? Today we will beat that record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandfather chuckles. Emilie indicates the larger barrier

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your jump. When I call you....be very brave and leap over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She claps, but Joey doesn't move. 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leap over it! Watch me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to her demonstration jump and easily steps over six-inch high barrier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now it's your --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to find Joey already stepping over her mini-jum stopping in front of her. He's only interested in the app in her hand. She takes a bite herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie returns Joey to the starting line and runs back be the big jump. From behind her back she produces three big carrots dripping soil. Joey's ears perk and he takes off quickly but at the last moment veers right and passes bet the two jumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandfather is watching through the window as he prepares strawberry jams. He laughs and goes back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aware she's being watched, she slings the carrots over he shoulder, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey slowly emerges from the barn with Emilie out in fron leading him with one hand. In the other hand, she carries small wooden step ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't think we can do it. But we will show him, won't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie unfolds the ladder beside Joey and shakily starts climbing to the top of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Her voice shaking) No need to be afraid. (Emilie looking down at how far off the ground

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are...very tall. 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before she can swing her leg over Joey's back -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll kill yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie turns, and there, blocking the hurdle, now standin hands on hips, is Grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if you get in my way to make me fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh please, come off the ladd--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SOUND from far down the road. Grandfather looks. Emilie turns to look too. Two trucks led by a German motorcycle approaching the farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find somewhere to hide them. And do it quickly!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Emilie races off with the horses, Grandfather pushes o the jumps and jams the pennant into his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bikes arrive first, just missing Emilie as she leads horses behind the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trucks arrive, pull round - one of the soldiers in th front jumps out and opens the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halt! Und aussteigen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people - 20 of them, all seeming to be poor French peasants, mainly women, move out of the truck. As they wa past, they avoid the eye of the Grandfather, who approach the soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Bonnard - this is my land. Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Food for the soldiers at the front. Everyone must give their share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And suddenly we see what is going to happen - the 20 peas spread out and move through the field - with either bags, using the aprons they wear - picking all the fruits - at the moment all the work has brought forth fruit - and the year's crop is ready. 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raspberries, black-currants, gooseberries. In a few minut everything he lives by will be gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching from his car and calmly smoking a cigar is BRAND the officer in charge of the unit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut to the fields - the aprons and baskets are getting fu They move through the rows of fruit like a plague of locu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to the Grandfather - and out of the house comes Emil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are taking everything. Where are the horses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What horses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of jars breaking draws Grandfather and Emilie i the kitchen, where the Germans continue to raid their oth supplies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One German picks up waterbath canner -- inspecting it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave it if you don't know what it's for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pot is a pot. We'll find some use for it. Sir, where's the livestock? Brandt sits quietly, casually using his finger to scoop j from an open jar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I make jam. We have no animals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there's fresh hay in your barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie enters, overhearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We use it to replace the mattress stuffings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her grandfather? 66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are her parents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're dead. They died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The German nods and is about to take his leave, putting t pot back where he found it, when a clumping noise from somewhere in the house begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind. It plays tricks in the attic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandt licks his finger and tests:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old house creaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go - close the shutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie runs out of the room. The soldier picks up the medicine bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's sickly, no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you or any of your friends harm her, as old as I am, I will kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldier looks shocked and then begins to laugh. He sl the medicine flask into Grandfather's chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I was going to give you back your pot. But now I'm going to keep it. For soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slings the huge pot he had put back up on his shoulder leaves the house with the other soldiers. 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will be back in the new season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Germans leave, we cut to the upstairs bedroom wher Emilie lies curled up on the bed - and there, standing on either side of the bed - are the two horses. They look hu in the tiny room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of shells exploding. A huge bombardment somewhe in the deep distance. But much closer than before. The distant, malicious giants of war growl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is like a lightning storm on the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen has been emptied. The war has finally come to them - and we can see it on Emilie's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what happened to them. To my mother and father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandfather doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you would tell me how they died. On my birthday. And tomorrow's my birthday! They died fighting, didn't they? But when the soldiers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finally turns to face him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - you do nothing. You are a coward, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. It was your parents who were brave. I make jams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you've never done a brave thing in your life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He eases himself into a chair and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe there are different ways to be brave. Did you know the French have the best carrier pigeons? And this could be the difference in the war - our messages getting through. 68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear about the birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are released at the front and told to go home - this is all they know. But to get there they must fly over a war. Can you imagine such a thing? Here you are flying over so much pain and terror - and you know you can never look down. You have to look forward or you'll never get home. I ask you - what could be braver than that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie sheds a single tear. INT. THE BARN. DAWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandfather enters the barn, strokes Topthorn's nose as h passes. He sweeps aside a rug from the barn floor, to rev a trap door. Then, he opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now from out of the trap door, he lifts a big ungainly object, covered in another rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie comes down the stairs as Grandfather waits proudly the stove. She stops when she sees the OBJECT COVERED BY RUG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie moves toward the object that is covered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you have not bought me a disgusting dress that I then have to wear like last year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was disgusting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I looked like an ugly nun. 69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she stops herself and turns to Grandfather with a parental rebuke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me your hand. (she takes it in hers) Grandpre, we have no money. When the war is over, then you can buy me jewels and carriages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grandfather smiles and gives Emily a hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything you say, my sweet one. Anything-you-say! You are, of course, the boss. It's just an old thing I found - don't worry yourself - leave it, I'll put it back. He leaves the room. Now Emilie is alone and she can't hel when she brings her eyes back to the object covered by th rug. She looks back over her shoulder to make sure she's being watched and then lifts one corner of the rug. Her f explodes with a gorgeous smile. She pulls off the rug tha is covering the big thing and...it is a gorgeous old sadd She runs her hand along the saddle -- can hardly believe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandfather helps to swing Emilie up and into the saddle. All at once, the Grandfather's charity evaporates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was your mother's. I hid it, so as not to encourage you. Emilie, I want you to ride very slowly, very carefully. And promise me you won't go far --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Okay, I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the top of the hill and straight back again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie unties her hair and tosses the red pennant to Grandfather, releasing her hair to spill down her back an shoulder. 70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sets off on Joey - and quickly spurs him to a gallop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly...slowly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rides - past the windmill - and then over the top of nearby hill - she speeds over it and out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to the hill - a sudden change of mood. An empty shot movement, no returning girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut again to the top of the hill, then back to the Grandfather, very worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Topthorn suddenly rears up - and charges off following, sensing danger. Grandfather starts to run in the directio the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Topthorn charging over the brow of the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Grandfather running - out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hears an indistinct scream from Emilie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches the top of the hill - comes over the brow - an there is not the fallen body of Emilie, which he has been fearing, but a brutal line of German soldiers - and motorbikes. It is like a line of Indians in a Western - total, alien fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there amongst them is Emilie, astride a panicked Joey surrounded by soldiers. Another one holds Topthorn, who b and rears, but to no avail. Grandfather starts down the h towards his granddaughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Germans are moving through the horses they have gathe Emilie, unhorsed, tries to get to Joey, who is being roug led away by a German soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Let go of me! No! 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandfather grabs her. She is screaming. He tries to calm down. Joey is tied up as is Topthorn. Emilie is kicking a screaming - but also desperately short of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is my granddaughter! Emilie, stop! Don't hurt her, please! Don't hurt her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A soldier roughly shoves Emilie at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandt approaches. Emilie screams at him, in tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need them! There are so many others!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie is still sobbing. Grandfather hugs her - in horror that she is now struggling so hard for breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, take the bigger one and leave the smaller one. You are breaking my granddaughter's heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The war has taken everything from everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will happen to them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They will pull artillery until they

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franois!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - or until the war is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will never be over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have your answer then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The motorbikes start up and drive off. The Grandfather hugging tiny Emilie as she coughs. 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Germans disappear up the lane leaving the old man and child bereft in the bitter cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two grooms trail Brandt, leading Joey and Topthorn toward makeshift corral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heiglemann - these are yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look strong - should last a month or two. FRIEDRICH is an unprepossessing, chubby man. He marvels a Topthorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then he looks to the other horses penned nearby, hagg and weak. He turns to Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a pity they found you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the leads of the pair of them. He sighs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such a pity...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a strange way, there are many humans Joey meets, but a just one, the spirit of goodness and consideration for animals, joined by little echoes throughout the film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then they go over a ridge - and we suddenly see the explanation of Friedrich's comment. The road they can see below them is the main through road of the area - and it scene of horse horror - huge, massive guns and cannons an artillery being dragged by teams of horses that are in a terrible condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Joey and Topthorn, this is a moment like when soldier arrived to liberate the prisoners who had been kept in Ch prison by the Japanese during World War 2. They have neve seen horses in this condition. You can see in their eyes confusion. This is a whole different world, where horses turn into creatures that look like this. 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it is also a vision of their future. This may be the moment the mighty Topthorn begins to lose hope. For Joey is another level of knowledge - another mighty thing he w fight through - because he always fights through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friedrich leads Joey and Topthorn in the wake of THE HUGE MORSER - an elaborate 15 ton monstrosity with a six inch bore. It takes a team of six horses to haul it with a doz men pushing from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull together!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A soldier calls from the front of the heavy cannon - pull by a particularly wretched group of horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halt! Halt! Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lower down the hill, Friedrich waves down the rest of the column.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop! Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the front of the Morser, one of the lead horses collap he will never get up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandt steps up, pulls a revolver out of his pocket and shoots the horse dead. It has come to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey, Topthorn, and all the other horses are spooked by t pistol shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandt shouts to Friedrich from the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heiglemann, bring up another one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heiglemann, bring up another horse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friedrich begins leading Joey up the hill, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. The big black one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friedrich hauls Topthorn, hesitantly, while Joey watches. 74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he reaches Brandt:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a good horse, sir. But if you move him up to the heavy gun, he will be no use at all. Prince is already losing condition. His leg, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have given them names?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should never give a name to anything you are certain to lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His leg is not good enough, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Private, you will do as you are told.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hook him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friedrich has no choice but as he starts to lead Topthorn Joey rears up and escapes his groom. He gallops up the hi to the gun - offering himself up to save Topthorn. It is "Tale of Two Cities" moment - giving up his life to save friend. He bucks and rears. Friedrich turns to Brandt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you see, sir, this one is stronger. Brandt takes up Friedrich, and Joey's, offer -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hook him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joey is hooked to the gun, he looks back to Friedrich leads Topthorn back down the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The convoy struggles up the hill. Joey feels the dead wei of the gun. These are several tons of cast iron - almost dwarfing the horses. Friedrich notices. Together, this gr circus struggles along the pot-holed country road in the rain. 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey leads the team up the incline. Each step is an immen effort. The going, over rough scree, is very tough indeed is very difficult for Joey to get a foothold on the loose ground, but his experience in Dartmoor comes into play an although he almost loses his balance several times he sta upright and hauls the cannon - Fitzcarraldo-like - over t hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow his progress step by step. Friedrich watches anxiously. Soldiers strain at the sides of the gun. One throws boards under the wheels to aid in traction. As the reach the top of the hill it almost seems the effort is t much, the cannon always in danger of rolling back. Joey finally staggers over the top - it feels as though the tethers are going to snap with the strain - but at last t cannon reaches the peak, the crest of the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soldiers scurry around the giant gun, preparing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halt! Halt! Take the horses away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friedrich observes with Topthorn as a giant shell is carr to the gun's breech.

dialogues.speaker: ARTILLERY OFFICER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And load!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men wrestle it into place -

dialogues.speaker: ARTILLERY OFFICER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Back! Case! - and secure it.

dialogues.speaker: ARTILLERY OFFICER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Position!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The barrel of the giant gun ratchets upward.

dialogues.speaker: ARTILLERY OFFICER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And...fire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shell explodes from the barrel. And then from another And another. For the first time we see the big picture - line of assembled cannons of which they were just one tin part. 76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each gun recoils violently as they shoot their shells int oblivion - as soon as one shell is fired another is loade the noise is deafening - the line seemingly endless - an obscene production line of death. This is what the horses have been feeding - this massive merciless thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke wafts from the guns as we see the explosions in the distance. The sound of the explosions takes us to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Explosions light the dirty faces of British boys in unifo one after the next. Each light fading out before the next great blast illuminates another anonymous face -then anot and then another - and then ALBERT. Hold on him for extra moments before he fades completely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the barrage lifted, the British soldiers that are huddled in a low sub-trench, are ordered back on the line Andrew Easton is with Albert and he's shaken and terrifie far cry from the happy young boy we knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gruff sergeant (SERGEANT MARTIN) walks the trench with bucket and each soldier puts in their valuables and perso belongings. One a lighter, some money, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valuables in the bucket, lads. If you live, you'll get them back. If you live, you'll get them back. Good lads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert and Andrew move down the trench in a line of soldi who are given ammo belts and grenades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert gets his grenades and walks further along the trenches. We follow him in real time as he passes a bunch soldiers who are kneeling in the ankle deep water, a PADR giving them communion. The deafening noise of shelling al around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's a drill, Albie. Maybe it's a drill like last time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We keep following Albert's progress in real time - furthe there is a post box where they all put their final letter home in identical green envelopes. We see Albert's letter addressed to "Ted and Rose Narracott" in Devon. He posts in a battered metal post box. 77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An officer approaches:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love letter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is David - Lyon's son - now in charge of this small gr of men. Still arrogant - looking older than Albert in his uniform - and clearly enjoying his superior rank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you and your mate were doing bird imitations again. You gonna write a letter to your horse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert ignores him. Andrew can't help but giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After you find your horse, I've lost my needle in a haystack, and I could use some help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David takes up a bucket and walks down the line of soldie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything valuable. Anyone who comes back gets to share it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert follows David down the trench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember that day me and Joey raced you in your car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember you somersaulting through the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that girl you were with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was. Don't you remember? 78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just some girl, I suppose. I don't recall which one. I do remember you falling on your bum in a ditch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew laughs amiably. David points to him, smirking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see? Always entertaining, Narracott, I'll give you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As David walks on, Andrew smiles at Albert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did that? You fell on your bum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert leaves without answering. Andrew keeps smiling unt a large shell explodes nearby. Troops surge towards their ladders as officers scream indistinct orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now David leads his troop through the trenches to the fro line where they stop, lean against the enemy-side wall nervously and wait - each man in private contemplation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant Martin moves along the lines, pushing men forwar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be ready! Be ready! Let's go, men, get ready to go! Get ready to move out! Stay in position!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David calls out from atop a trench ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold your nerve, boys. Remember, it's not far to go. There's a way through. (he moves down the line) Run fast, keep your wits about you, keep your eyes open and God and the King will keep an eye on you. Company will fix bayonets! Fix bayonets!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The echo of `fix bayonets' goes down the line - and every fixes the brutal shining bayonet to the end of his gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Albert turns to Andrew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what it reminds me of out there? 79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That bloody impossible lower field the day me and Joey plowed it. Best day of my life that was and you were there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this here is the worst day of my life, about to begin, and you're here cheering me on. Us two, always. And him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods at David Lyons, who gives instructions to another soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once you're in no man's land, go to the flanks. Stay on the flanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David turns to Albert and Andrew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, boys, come on. To the ladder!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stick close to the gentry, that's our ticket, yeah? We have the pluck but they have the luck. They both smile. And then the fear takes over again. Andr particularly feels as though he is on the very edge now. David urges them forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, too, Narracott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew and Albert pass by the bucket. They throw some valuables in. But a moment later, Albert goes back to the bucket and pulls something out - a worn piece of paper - unfolds it - it is the little sketch that Captain Nicholl drew of Joey the night before they left for France. He sl it inside his shirt, next to his heart. 80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, on your ladders, boy. On your ladders. In you go, in you go. That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew turns towards a ladder. As fate and placement woul have it - he is first in line. He puts his foot on the ladder, when suddenly the Sergeant stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to your sergeant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls Andrew aside, speaking so that everyone can hear

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If anybody turns back, if any one of our boys come running towards you - you take this rifle and you shoot them dead. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sergeant pushes in on Andrew, private and intense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand me? Do you understand what I'm telling you, son? You take this rifle and you shoot them dead. Understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew looks ready to cry, but manages to nod. Albert tur to him, only to be pushed back by the sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up there, son. Up your ladder. Up your ladder to your work! Albert looks nervously back at Albert, comforting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good. Andrew, it's good. Andrew! Nobody's retreating today. Andrew! Andrew! Nobody. Is retreating. Today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The COMMANDER arrives, checks the time on his AIDE's watc mounts his ladder and blows a whistle to signal the charg A BAGPIPER plays as the men go over the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David now heads up the ladder first. Gun fire overhead, Albert steels himself, then hauls himself over the top, followed by the next man and the next. 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immediately machine gun fire whistles past, we hear the screams of the first men who are shot. We follow Albert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are him. His vision. His experience. The ground is blasted, there are bodies all around him. He tries to run his feet sink into the mud. Bullets fly past him. Felled are screaming at his feet in fear and agony. Albert stagg forward. David is now right by him. They run together. Al looks round and suddenly, David is hit. He falls to the ground, screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm shot! No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert instinctively goes to help. Bullets shower all aro him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just leave me. Leave me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert grabs him and drags him onwards with him - David screaming at the pain - Albert grimly determined. Shells explode around them as they stumble on. Other men are running and falling. Albert sees cover in a huge shell-ho so dives into it for a moment's reprieve from the gun fir He sits in still terror for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be all right here. You'll be safe. Someone'll come for ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert. Albert, listen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. It's all right. We're Devon boys, yeah? David looks at Albert as though seeing him for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert races onward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back at the trench, Andrew waits - terrified - and then, out of the mist step two men - heading back towards him. a third. They suddenly catch sight of Andrew waiting ther with his gun pointed towards them. They slow down - in th terror of the assault, they had forgotten that death was waiting for them if they turned back. 82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time seems to slow down - Andrew shifts his gun from poin at one - to the other - we see their individual faces. Th are all just boys really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And suddenly, instinct hits Andrew - he charges up the ladder, and forward, firing - past the three men, towards enemy. He chooses his death instead of theirs. A sudden barrage of machine gun fire all around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut back to Albert, who makes his way to the edge of the shell hole. Bullets whizz inches from his head. He looks to see a German machine gun position to his right. Bullet whizz past forcing him to duck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew charges past other soldiers, ignoring their warnin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get down! Albert continues forward to dive into another shell hole, nearer to the German line. He scrambles from shell hole t shell hole. Now he's very close to the machine gun positi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert takes a grenade, fumbles with the pin as his hands tremble. He finally gets the pin out and he hurls the grenade at the machine gunner. We see the explosion and t machine gun stop. Albert sprints over the top again and m it all the way into the German trench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert runs through the trench, which seems curiously emp Albert swings round as he sees the startling face of a ga masked German holding a rifle on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert readies his bayonet but the man is dead, slumped backwards against the side of the trench still upright. Albert spins round, his bayonetted rifle in front of him, ready for action, but there is only the ghostly sight of German soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert is alone, everyone else is dead. All the dead wear gas masks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More British soldiers drop into the trench, among them Andrew. He stumbles in the mud, drops his rifle, recovers it, and races through the trench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glimpses Albert ahead of him, stalking through the mis Andrew breaks into a smile and rushes forward, prompting Albert to whirl with his rifle raised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert pauses just in time. Then he collapses against the side of the trench, overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew grabs Albert and holds him up, embracing him. Albe can barely whisper:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We made it. We made it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment later, the pair of them hurry through the trench Albert spots more comrades around a corner and calls ahea Andrew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew, this way out! Suddenly ANOTHER SOLDIER leaps from a trench branch betwe them, shouting in panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gas! Gas! Gas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An instant later, a gas cloud blasts through the trench. Andrew and Albert look in horror. It spreads towards them too powerful to avoid. Andrew is closest, turns to Albert with a helpless -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - before he takes the full power of it. An instant later, white, deadly cloud encompasses Albert, too...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. EDGE OF THE BATTLEFIELDS. DUSK.
dialogues.text: Close on hooves and boots, slogging through muddy water, several inches deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friedrich is walking along, leading Topthorn and Joey. Topthorn is limping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something is wrong - Topthorn seems to be failing - he co badly, breathes strangely. Friedrich stops to check on hi An officer notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, there's no stopping here. Keep them moving. 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, there's something wrong. This one needs to rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no rest for them. Move them along. Move them along!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instead, Friedrich leads the horses under the cover of a bridge for a brief respite. A moment later, Topthorn collapses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, please, please. Stay on your feet. No, please. No no no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friedrich tries to help Topthorn valiantly struggling to up but finally sinks to the ground again. This time he li semi-conscious. He is dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please please... Stay on your feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey deeply upset nuzzles his nose into Topthorn but the drains out him. Friedrich is in panic at Topthorn's quick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Please please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friedrich continues to stroke Topthorn's head. Joey pushe Topthorn as if to stop him falling into unconsciousness. a moment we think Topthorn will come round but he slips a and all life leaves his body. Friedrich solemnly strokes horse, knowing all is lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey does not understand. He pulls at Topthorn's reins, a trying to pull him upright. Topthorn's body is inert, his head falls to the earth. Joey will not give up, he pulls him desperately not understanding that Topthorn has died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Friedrich looks around. Chaos - all the German soldiers stream back past their position, scrambling to g their guns and helmets. An officer charges down the bank to the bridge, screaming orders at Friedrich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're coming! Leave it, private!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friedrich tries to pull Joey away to safety but Joey will leave Topthorn's body. Friedrich pulls at Joey, but Joey too lost in his grief to care about or even notice the danger. 85.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN OFFICER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Leave it! Come with me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to hell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officer nods to two other soldiers who pull Friedrich safety. As he's dragged away, he screams at Joey:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run. Run! Run! Run!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this is all background noise to Joey's profound refus to accept Topthorn is dead. He paws at the ground next to Topthorn, a horse standing over his best friend in a fiel and he will never leave him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then suddenly - from around a blind turn in the streambed, a huge, remorseless tank turns, heading right Joey. He bolts, galloping down the streambed, until he reaches a barbed wire barrier - a dead end. He attempts t run up the banks, but they're blocked, as well. He rears but the tank keeps advancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tank is about to crush Joey. He has left it too late. is about to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then, counter-intuitively, he runs straight towards t tank and...leaps over it - a leap he learnt from Emilie. scrambles up and over it and leaps down behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey keeps on running. He is wild, frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey is free - in countryside - but there is blood pourin from his leg, clearly torn by his encounter with the tank runs on - it is becoming night - suddenly there are explosions to the left of him - this fast, elegant creatu simply runs through the gaps between explosions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But as he charges on - the sky lights up in the direction is heading. He is suddenly in the thick of battle. A shel explodes next to him, and he leaps entirely over a trench Another explosion sends him leaping, but not far enough - finds himself crashing downwards, and into a trench - and races through it - and finds himself charging towards a German company. Both sides are equally startled - Joey charging through a thin trench lined with German soldiers the soldiers, finding a live horse careering through them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In desperation, Joey scrambles out of the trench - and on again, rushes away from the fighting... 86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now it is very dark indeed - he is stumbling as he ru there is blood mixed with the mud on his legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it is total night - fog - confusion - he jumps again. now everywhere there are potholes - the land is massively uneven - shells are exploding all around. And suddenly se in front of him barbed wire. He crashes through it - more he bursts through again - now dragging barriers behind hi the barriers tangle, pulling him up short - he flips and lands amongst even more barbed wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls and turns to release himself but it is impossibl The more he pulls, the more firmly he is trapped. He rise up, wild, magnificent, a beast fighting for his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is completely trapped. He cannot move. He cannot see. is in pain. He falls. It feels like an end. EXT. BRITISH TRENCH. THE SAME.

dialogues.speaker: GEORDIE SOLDIER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Stand to, stand to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young soldier, a Geordie, is on look-out duty. He looks through a periscope. He alerts his colleague in his thick northern, Newcastle accent.

dialogues.speaker: GEORDIE SOLDIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There's something moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like a cow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He passes the periscope to the second soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell would a cow be doing out there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see what he sees - nothing but morning mist on the sur landscape - and something strange. It is Joey in the dist

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That definitely isn't a cow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing over periscope) Well, what is it? 87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see an almost identical scene of several German soldie looking out at Joey just as the British soldiers had done

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can't be a horse. Nothing alive could be out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't a horse. It isn't a horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first German looks through his periscope. We see what sees - Joey in the mist:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes - it's a horse. The second German looks through the periscope, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A third German (PETER) lowers his binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's a horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now all the soldiers are gathering to look out at Joey. A CAPTAIN now has the periscope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, bugger me. It's a horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lads, we should call him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you call a horse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geordie starts clicking his tongue, followed by all o his comrades. They all try to attract Joey's attention wi tongue clicks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Germans hear the clicks and respond with a chorus of whistles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now both sides are whistling. Even the captain joins in. 88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey tries to rise, but remains entangled. He whinnies in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter lowers his binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's caught on the wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sod it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geordie climbs up the side of the trench, and waves a whi handkerchief tied to the end of his bayonet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think you're doing? Get back, do you hear me? Corporal, that's an order! Get back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geordie, not receiving fire, is emboldened to stand up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to him, sir. We can't leave him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves the handkerchief to clearly signal he is no thre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Germans look at the young soldier making his way over Man's Land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a trap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so. I think he's trying to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second German cocks his rifle and starts to take aim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scare him back into his hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second German takes a shot aimed over the Geordie's shoulder. 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geordie crouches for cover, waving his handkerchief m frantically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a white flag, ent it? You see the white flag!? I'm just after tending to this here horse, is all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Georgie marshals his courage and stands again, waving handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back, you stupid git!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no fire from the German trenches. Muttering to himself, the Geordie marches forward towards Joey:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want, he leadeth me into green pastures, he lay me down beside the still waters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geordie walks very slowly across the mud - there are bodies - the ground squelches beneath his feet. He waves handkerchief as he walks. He crosses a narrow bridge that spans a flooded bomb crater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey, lying on his side, wrapped head to toe in barbed wi covered in mud, watches Geordie approach. When Geordie ge too close, Joey freaks out and begins thrashing about. Jo whinnies a high scream of pain, because wire is cutting i his hide in several places, and as he thrashes it cuts hi deeper. Particularly worrisome is a strand that's wrapped around his head, crossing right over his eye, threatening slash it. The Geordie calls out in a soothing voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor beastie. Poor babbie. It's alright. It's alright. Don't buck and wriggle so, you're only shredding yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey calms a little, still moving his head up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll blind yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches Joey and surveys the formidable tangle of wire which Joey's bundled. The Geordie soothes and at the same time gingerly tests other strands, trying to figure out w to begin. 90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bugger me worthless - I didn't think to bring gloves or something to cut

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stabs his hand on one of the barbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a noise behind him, and the Geordie turns around see the Peter (the German from the trench) standing sever feet away, holding some wire cutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought perhaps you might need these. He holds out the wire cutters. The Geordie, still frightened, stares stupidly at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the barbed wire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah I... Ummm, thanks. Cheers. Cheers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches out and takes the proffered cutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
