dialogues.text: He returns to Joey, nervous about turning his back. He tr to figure out where to begin cutting. He lifts a long str of wire that wraps around Joey's neck, stretches across h shoulder and torso and around one of his front legs. He p the wire in the crux of the cutters and is preparing to s when Peter steps closer to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That...That's a very long strand. When you cut it, it's going to release this -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to a wire wrapped around the wire the Geordie's lifting. Then he points to two other wires, similarly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and this, and this, and they'll coil back rather violently, which I'm afraid will only wound the poor fellow further. 91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geordie nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You speak good English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I speak English well. (re: the cutters) May I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geordie hands them over and Peter surveys the wires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if we cut his head free first? So he won't try to stand up and blind himself? And then -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pity you didn't bring a second pair. Then I could cut the wire here -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to one of the wires entangled with the strand h been prepared to cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter stands and shouts in the direction of his trench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All at once one, two, three, six pairs of cutters come soaring through the air and splash into the watery crater

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later - Peter and the Geordie kneel beside Joey, with a pair of cutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey is calming down again. The Geordie positions himself across Joey's body so that he's cut the wire, it won't coil back and cut Joey. Peter positions himself to be able to cut the two wires in quic succession, holding the first wire to stop it from spring back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey's completely still now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter points between Joey's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His blind spot. The cutters won't frighten him. If you could cut here, holding this wire -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to wires that intersect the wire that crosses Joey's eye. Then he points to the wire across Joey's eye. 92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say no more, I'm right behind you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they reposition themselves, the Geordie says to Joey:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you understand what's happening, do you not, O Best Beloved? That you must lay so very nice and still. There's a lad, you're a remarkable horse, you are, helping us help you. There's a lad. There's a remarkable lad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geordie looks into Joey's huge eye as he and Peter ge work on their cutting. Joey returns his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how's things in yonder trench?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delightful. We read, we knit sweaters, and we train our rats to perform circus tricks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if ever you need any more rats, we can always send ours over. `Cause we've more than we need, strictly speaking. Besides, they scare off all the pretty girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our girls aren't afraid of rats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big strapping German girls, eh? Kind what gives robust massages?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every Thursday! And they bring rum cake on your birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both men smile at this while Joey is completely still; th work quickly, in concert, cutting the horse's head free o the wire. 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey raises his head, gives it a shake, neighs and then s a little. The two soldiers smile at one another. Then the set about cutting the rest of the wire; it's much easier

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geordie cuts through the last wire binding Joey's leg The two soldiers help as the horse staggers upright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that horse! Look at the muscles he's got, them long legs. They're made for running, horses. Runnin' away from danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Running away is all they have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet we taught `em opposite. Running into the fray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: War horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. War horse. And there he is. What a strange beast you've become.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geordie grabs hold of Joey's halter, though Joey show sign of running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey is finally free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take him back with me, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since I supplied the cutters, the horse is mine. This is fair, no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a pig's eye. He's English, plain to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you mean because he's so filthy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he's so smart. And you're none too clean yourself. 94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could box. And the winner gets the horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geordie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks, pet. Must be careful not to start a war. (patting his pockets:) Do you have a coin of any sort?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coin toss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He takes a coin from his pocket, hands it to the Geordie, looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Fritz - you're on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flips the coin back to Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is not Fritz - it is Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter - I'm Colin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call it, Colin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heads. Peter spins it in the air and lets it fall into the mud. look down. Peter shakes his head, resigned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the face of my Kaiser and he does not look pleased with me. The horse is yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They collect their helmets as snow begins to blow around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone quiet, hasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But wait half an hour and we'll be shooting again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a terrible shot, Pete, don't believe I'll ever hit the target.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands back the cutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He notices the Geordie has offered his hand, as well. A beat, then Peter shakes with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheerio, mate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll take good care of him, yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our strange beast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you take care of your own strange self.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter tosses Geordie his cutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colin! A pair of German cutters - in memory of your handsome friend from Dusseldorf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter nods, and walks back to his trench. As he goes, the Geordie calls after him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll use `em back in the garden in South Shields. You keep your head down, now, Pete me lad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he walks away, Peter turns back briefly, calling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remarkable! A remarkable horse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geordie leads Joey towards the British trenches. 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey is now in the trenches, splashing about in the ankle deep water. He seems enormous in this cramped labyrinth. is led past the broken and wounded soldiers who look at h with amazement, dumbfounded. It is a surreal image. The h where horses shouldn't be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joey makes his journey through the trenches soldiers excitedly gather to watch him come by, taking pleasure in saving of this single life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We arrive at a section we recognise as the place from whe Albert set off only the night before. Sergeant Martin is there - as one man helps a wounded soldier into a medical area. It is David, hobbling and looking shell-shocked. Another wounded soldier approaches, but Martin waves him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're full up. Move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is seated next to Albert, who now seems in worse condition. His eyes are bandaged and he's wheezing. Andre is nowhere to be seen. As a MEDICAL OFFICER checks Albert

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gas got him - we had to wait till morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The medic moves to Sergeant Martin, looking stricken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This can't be all of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all. (bellowing to the men) All walking wounded, away to the dressing station! Away to the dressing station!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey is led into the hospital area beyond the trenches. T Geordie leads him through the snowy streets. Bandaged men strewn around, wounded soldiers waiting for attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiting soldiers gather to view the strange spectacle the horse. 97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At one of the dressing areas, a NURSE tends to Albert's damaged eyes. Behind him, we see Joey pass in the street, but Albert doesn't know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey limps, his foreleg clearly injured. The Geordie sold stops outside a makeshift hospital. Joey looks frail and exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DOCTOR storms over from his patients.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need a vet, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no vets. We've scarcely any horses left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's cut all over, but this leg here's got the worst of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geordie strokes Joey as the Doctor examines him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's probably tetanus. It's no good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, sir -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor heads back into the hospital, dismissive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've all these men to take care of, corporal, you can see that, can't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, sir, this horse can pull through anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor absorbs his earnest appeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elsewhere, a line of soldiers waiting for medical assista are curious about what is going on. Blinded by gas, eyes bandaged, one of them turns toward the commotion. It is Albert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? 98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a horse they found, wandering about in No Man's Land. (easing him back onto a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of an horse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody miraculous kind of an horse, be my guess. Nothing makes it out of No Man's Land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert lies there, but can't let go of the thought:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miraculous horse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey stands - breathing very deeply. The Doctor touches h wounded leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men from all over the medical area gather around Joey concerned about their new hero's pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor looks at the Geordie and frowns shaking his he "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the doctor:) He was alive, y'see, sir, where nothing survives, so to me and me mates, to the men, sir, he's - Well, we have high hopes for him -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should shoot him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geordie is broken hearted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'd be a mercy, lad, that leg's not going to mend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor sadly addresses a nearby Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant. Put him out of his misery. 99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor nods his head towards Joey. The sergeant, SERG FRY, takes his gun from his holster, checks that it's loa He turns to some nearby NURSES, urging them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies, if you please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Total silence from the crowd who have gathered. They thou they were there to see something wonderful. And now they that they've gathered for an execution - but can't take t eyes off it. The Sergeant waves them back.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT FRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All right, back off. Back off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geordie is the last to step away from Joey. The serge draws breath - before he steps forward to take aim. Joey totally still, sensing the atmosphere. The sergeant cocks his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly there is a strange owl like whistle from fifty y away. Joey looks around startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sergeant turns Joey's head back around, raises his pi once more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, the whistle again. Even the doctor notices this tim

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey turns. Slowly, the crowd parts - another owl whistle and we see Albert, his eyes bandaged - walking forward blindly - guided by the hands of the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One soldier urges Albert gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. Do it again. One more whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this time, Joey trots over to Albert. The horse nuzzl into him. Albert can't see Joey but he touches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Joey. Hello boy. Where you been then, hey? Where in the world you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strokes Joey's mane. Joey responds, becoming very stil The Doctor approaches with the Geordie. 100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Geordie:) Do you know this man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geordie shakes his head, no. The Doctor speaks to Alb gently; clearly he thinks he's dealing with a traumatized possibly crazy soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert, realizing he's being addressed, turns to the doct

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Narracott, Private Albert Narracott, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a random horse, Narracott, and too badly injured. (to the orderly) Is this man in your care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not random at all, sir! He's my horse, I raised him, in Devon. Sir, look at his legs! He's got four white socks, he's brown all over - (points to his own

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and he has a white mark here - like so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes the shape of a diamond with his hands. The docto turns to the orderly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! You can't see `cause of the mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geordie looks around, spots a bucket of water, grabs and uses a rag to clean Joey's legs, revealing the socks. Geordie looks at the doctor. 101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four white socks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor takes a rag himself and wipes Joey's snout, revealing the white diamond mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sergeant takes this in...and holsters his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, break it up. Clear off, the lot of ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, sir? He's not random at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor steps up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will attend to your horse. Patch him up best we can. Treat him like the soldier he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With one last amazed look at Albert and Joey, the doctor returns to the hospital area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later - Albert, the Geordie, and Sergeant Fry all lead Joey through the snowy street together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant Fry strides into the middle of the throng of soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen! Gentlemen! It falls on me to give you some important news. At eleven o'clock today, in two minutes time - the War will come to an end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shock from the troops. Strangely muted. Not the explosion emotion you might have expected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert enters, his eyes still red, but no longer bandaged

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT FRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The King and Queen thank you for your service. We have been victorious - even if at a higher price than many of us might have imagined.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT FRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When the bells ring out - and they will in a moment, for the first time for four years - let us remember our brothers fallen in the field. And thank God for the end of this struggle and victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, in the distance, the church bells ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey stands tall, eating some hay, now healed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Complete change of atmosphere. Silence. Tension. Albert stands at attention with Sergeant Fry. A severe Major is behind his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officers' horses only. All other horses are to be auctioned immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is a complete and bloody outrage. It's the lad's horse, sir, from Devon. He raised him up from a pup, he did. Trained him right up to the day when the army came to town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These aren't my orders, sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to take him to market. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert puts on a brave face as he collects Joey and leads out of the stables in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Albert comes out the men have gathered. There's a stra sense of optimism, for such a gloomy moment. The Geordie comes up to Albert and hands him a sheaf of pound notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've all clubbed together. It's everything we have. There's twenty-nine pounds there. Buy him back. 103.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does the Major know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Major put in ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geordie flashes a sly wink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mum's the word where the Major's concerned. Your friend on the crutches over there -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to indicate David Lyons, who nods at Albert solemnly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - even asked the Major to say that Joey was his, an officer's horse, so that he could go back with the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert is amazed. He is about to show his gratitude when sergeant major shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Narracott! Get a move on. We don't want to miss the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert snaps to attention and begins to lead Joey out of parade ground with the other horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk off, the sergeant silently adds some of his money to the notes in Albert's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The intense bustle of the market. Farmers are gathered, bidding for horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven pounds! Seven pounds there! Seven pounds! Eight pounds here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A groom leads Joey to the auction pen with other horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight pounds! Ten pounds here! Any advance? Sold!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert waits anxiously, the Geordie lad by his side, as J is led into the pen. 104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're alright. Nobody's gonna bid more than fifteen for a thoroughbred. They want work horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The auctioneer starts the bidding on Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next one. We start at four pounds. Four pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The farmers seem disinterested, shaking of heads. The bid starts. Five pounds, six, seven, now it goes slowly, eigh nine, ten. Albert looks pleased at how it's going. He fee the cash in his hand. It seems to stick on ten, then a ne hand comes up at the back of the auction - it is a nasty looking moustached man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant Fry scowls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the butcher from Cambrai. He's been bidding for the best all morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven. Eleven pounds. Eleven pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me handle this, private. (he calls out) ) Fifteen, and let that be an end to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks daggers at the Butcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixteen pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty of your English pounds. And let THAT be the end of it, my friend. 105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty Five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty five pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty Six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty six pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are all looking very worried... There's not much left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty eight pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any advance at thirty pounds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, from the back, another, new French voice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps to the front of the crowd, and suddenly we see w it is. It is Emilie's Grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And sir, if you bid against me, I will sell the coat on my back and bid to one hundred and ten. And if you bid against me again, I will sell my farm and bid to a thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks at Albert who is devastated. Albert is reeling. He hears the auctioneer repeat the final amount brings down his gavel. 106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred pounds. Going, going, gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers slowly disperse, leaving Albert to stare at Joey. It really is all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Grandfather finishes paying for Joey. Albert and the Geordie stand in front of the grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I'll give you all your money. Everything you paid when we get back to England. I'll give you twice -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know anything about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but you're wrong, sir, I know everything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you found him! I heard you found a horse in the wire between the armies -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I found him, he raised him -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Grandfather goes to Joey and takes his reins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I heard about the miracle horse, I traveled three days because I knew whose horse it was. My granddaughter's. She saved his life! He was everything to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses, briefly, to collect himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is your granddaughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The war has taken everything from everyone. He is all that I have left of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Grandfather leads Joey away. Joey pulls, firmly but n wildly, on the rein the grandfather's holding. The grandfather lets go. 107.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches as Joey walks to Albert and nuzzles him. They a moment together. The Grandfather watches carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert puts his face right near Joey - speaks gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be worried, boy, when I go. I won't worry over you none. Hey, I found you, didn't I, and you found me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandfather softens and begins to wonder about this soldi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we'll both... we'll both know that we made it through. Now go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads Joey back to the Grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're the lucky ones. Always have been. Lucky since the day I met you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He quietly hands over the reins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God be with you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grandfather looks at Albert, then takes the regimenta pennant from his pocket:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what this is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert's amazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my father's. It's his regimental pennant. How did you come by this, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandfather hands Albert the pennant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may have this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert takes the pennant and looks at it, his eyes fillin with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you ever so much for this, sir... 108.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a sigh) ... And this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands Albert Joey's reins. Albert turns to face him, almost mute with disbelief. He reaches for his money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no, not necessary. He belongs to you. That is, of course, what my little girl would have wanted. And she was the boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandfather laughs, then turns and slowly walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie. (turns back with a smile) Her name is Emilie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert gently embraces Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, we are back in the village in Devon, in the fol the valley. Dusk light. A figure approaches, silhouetted against the setting sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Naracott gathers the harvest, then notices as the fi makes its way up the road to the farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man in uniform. On a magnificent horse. Mrs. Narracott meets them at the gate and we can finally see them clearl Albert and Joey. Albert dismounts and removes his cap. An instant later, M Narracott is hugging him for all that her life is worth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted sees them and makes his way to the field gate...shaky Albert approaches, and stops a slight distance away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted opens the gate to stand before his son. Albert slips something from his pocket and lets it unfurl in his hand Ted's campaign pennant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted accepts it quietly, then offers his hand to Albert. T shake, as men. And then slowly embrace, as father and son 109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Narracott joins them as Joey looks on - a small fami and a beautiful horse, finally home.
